title: Forest Fitness
description:
Date: April 2, 2022

Join the Fort Tryon Park Trust for a free, year-round “Fitness at the Fort” exercise program on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays! This regular fitness class incorporates climbing multiple staircases, stretches and strengthening exercises, notable tree identification, and forest bathing. Led by Nancy Bruning, BA, MPH, PAPHS.

Tuesdays at 7:30 a.m.: Easy Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance. Walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretching and cardio stair climbing. Walk south to Cabrini Woods for cardio steps and strengthening exercises and walk uphill to Billings Overlook for closing stretches.

Thursdays at 7:30 a.m.: Moderate Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance and walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretching and cardio stair climbing. Walk along the western path to Broadway, incorporating strengthening exercises, and walk uphill past Gazebo/Dog Run to Café Lawn, end with stretches.

Saturdays at 8:30 a.m.: Intense Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance and walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretch and cardio stair climbing. Walk along the western path to Broadway, incorporating strengthening exercises. Walk uphill towards Gazebo/Dog Run, utilizing a cluster of steps west of Broadway Path. Walk along the upper Alpine Garden path, to volleyball courts for stretches with final stair climbing to Margaret Corbin Circle.

(Note: Fitness Walking does not meet if it is raining or if the actual temperature or wind chill is below 20 degrees F.)

Start time: 8:30 am

End time: 9:30 am

Contact phone: 2127951388

Location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)
location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)
categories: Nature | Fitness | Seniors | Hiking | Exercise Classes | Strength Training/Weightlifting | Walking

title: It's My Park at Seward Park
description:
Date: April 2, 2022

This It's My Park season, volunteer with Seward Park Conservancy as we enter the gated meadow of the garden in Seward Park to remove old plants. This will involve pulling old plants for transplant, weeding, and then if time allows we will be trying to put new plants into the ground. This is part of our plan to turn the meadow into a "Pollinator Place", which will be filled with native plants. The non-native plants will be ideally moved to other areas of the garden and new native plants will be added. We look forward to working with you on this project into the spring season!

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 12:00 pm

title: Spring Cleaning at Schmul Park
description:
Date: April 2, 2022

Join the Freshkills Park Alliance and NYC Parks for a volunteer day at Schmul Park and discover ways to get creative in our green spaces and support the bees! Ages 12+

We will work together to remove invasive plant species and litter, learn how to establish complex pollinator ecosystems, and highlight all the ways pollinators support our parks and our planet!

Please note: As per NYC Parks policy, volunteers must sign an activity waiver and will be required to show proof they have received two doses of the Pfizer or Moderna vaccine, or the one dose of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine in order to participate.

Plan Ahead: Wear long pants, close-toed shoes, and insect repellant. Also wear a hat and bring water and a snack. Tools, gloves, masks, and sanitizer will be provided. Do not attend if you are sick or have been exposed to COVID-19.

Can't make it? You can still help by promoting our volunteer projects with your friends and neighbors. Students can receive credit for community service hours. We will also be adding more volunteer opportunities as the season continues. For more information about upcoming volunteer opportunities at freshkillspark.org/volunteer.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 12:00 pm

Contact phone: (917) 533-3281

Location: Schmul Park

title: Bronx Urban Nature and Nature's Beauty
description:
Date: April 2, 2022

Enjoy an exhibition of photographs and graphics by Bronx artist Roy Secord rendered from nature photography shot during the pandemic.

Beautiful nature is closer than you think. This exhibition showcases the beauty of Bronx nature locations, many in close proximity to Poe Park. Roy Secord's work inspires viewers to explore and respectfully enjoy the incredible nature around us for our physical and psychological well-being.

“Nature’s Beauty” by Ace Photographers: Bronx Youth Nature Photography Program

An exhibition of nature photography by Roy Secord’s fine art and nature photography program by Bronx IS339 Middle School students. Sponsored by NYC Artist Corps Grant.

Wake Up, Daisy! tells the story of Daisy, a lively little girl living in the heart of New York City in an apartment overlooking Central Park. At Daisy’s much-anticipated birthday party, she encounters three special guests, known as her “Squad-parents”, from Brooklyn, Queens, and the Bronx who grant her the gifts of courage, knowledge, and a second chance. When an unwelcome guest shows up and casts a curse on her, Daisy’s life is forever changed. But through the support of her friends and an adventure throughout the city, Daisy’s strong self-determination and vivid imagination may be all she needs to break the curse.

title: It's My Park at Wolfe's Pond Park
description:
Date: April 2, 2022

DIG+RIDE = FUN

Join NYCMTB on the First Saturday of each month to help, build, ride, and maintain the trails at Wolfe's Pond park in Staten Island. Volunteers help conduct our monthly trail inspection and perform routine maintenance tasks; such as litter pickup, raking, erosion control(digging) and trail maintenance. This volunteer event starts at 11:00am rain or shine.

Optional group ride 10am-11am - Join us for off-road only riding on the Wolfe's Pond Park Trails The Route: Mostly beginner friendly Distance: ~7 miles

Both parties meet at: Wolfe's Pond Park Maintenance Shop 475 Cornelia Ave Staten Island, NY 10312

Please register ahead of time: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/first-saturdays-wolfes-pond-tickets-231731624527?aff=erelexpmlt

ATTENTION VOLUNTEERS -- PLEASE REVIEW THIS COVID-19 SAFETY INFORMATION

Perform a self-health check at home to see if you may be sick with the coronavirus. If you exhibit any of the following symptoms, please do NOT volunteer.

  • Cough
  • Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing
  • Fever
  • Chills
  • Muscle pain
  • Sore throat
  • New loss of taste or smell

Wear a face covering. People who do not show symptoms may still be able to spread COVID-19. A face covering can help prevent you from spreading COVID-19 to other people, so you should wear one whenever you leave home and cannot maintain at least six feet of distance from others. A face covering can include anything that covers your nose and mouth including dust masks, scarves, and bandanas, but an N95 mask remains the most effective at preventing the spread of coronavirus. These are readily available at most retailers stocking masks.

Start time: 11:00 am

End time: 3:00 pm

title: Family Nature Walk
description:
Date: April 2, 2022

Lace up your shoes for a nature walk at Freshkills Park! Freshkills Park staff will take you behind the scenes to visit areas that are currently closed to the public. On this one-mile walk, you’ll learn about the different plants and animals found in the woods, wetlands, and grasslands at Freshkills Park.

There is a $10 suggested donation per participant. Your donation supports the education, programming, and research at the Freshkills Park Alliance and makes programs like this possible.

You will be asked to sign an activity waiver before participating in the program.

Register Online

Your ticket admits 1 car. Because of COVID-19 restrictions, all participants must provide their own car that will stay on-site the whole time. Participants may not use a bicycle, taxi or ride-share service. Each ticket holder may bring up to 4 additional guests in their car. During registration, you will be asked about additional participants in your car. Due to limited reservations, carpooling with friends and family is encouraged.

Accessibility: We will be walking approximately 1-mile on a gravel trail, which includes elevation and can be uneven at times. An ADA-accessible portable toilet will be available at the beginning and end of the walk.

title: Wake Up, Daisy! at the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre
description:
Date: April 3, 2022

For more information on the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre, our COVID-19 policy and to purchase tickets, visit our website.

Wake Up, Daisy! tells the story of Daisy, a lively little girl living in the heart of New York City in an apartment overlooking Central Park. At Daisy’s much-anticipated birthday party, she encounters three special guests, known as her “Squad-parents”, from Brooklyn, Queens, and the Bronx who grant her the gifts of courage, knowledge, and a second chance. When an unwelcome guest shows up and casts a curse on her, Daisy’s life is forever changed. But through the support of her friends and an adventure throughout the city, Daisy’s strong self-determination and vivid imagination may be all she needs to break the curse.

title: Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy
description:
Date: April 4, 2022

See Frederick Law Olmsted’s lasting influence on park innovation in New York City with “Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy,” on view at the Arsenal Gallery in Central Park. The commemorative exhibition looks at recent NYC Parks projects that incorporate various Olmsted design principles, including site responsiveness, respect for nature, and the orchestration of movement. With renderings, site plans, and photos, the show highlights 10 park renovations throughout the city:

  • Bronx: Hugh Grant Circle/Virginia Park and Concrete Plant Park
  • Brooklyn: Lincoln Terrace Playground and Sunset Park Playground
  • Manhattan: Monsignor Kett Playground and Central Park’s Harlem Meer Center (formerly Lasker Rink and Pool)
  • Queens: Elmhurst Park and Bayswater Park
  • Staten Island: Faber Park and Richmond Terrace

April 26, 2022 marks the 200th anniversary of the birth of Frederick Law Olmsted (1822-1903), a pioneer landscape architect famous for his work co-designing Central Park, Prospect Park, and other well-known urban green spaces. From the democratization of public parks to the contouring of landscape and terrain to create a variety of visual experience, Olmsted was a seminal force in the design of our parks and how they are used.

Image: Concrete Plant Park, Bronx, 2009, NYC Parks / Jim Mituzas

Please note: Mask-wearing is required to enter the Arsenal Gallery, and guests are required to sign in. Groups of five or more people can call (212) 360-8114 or email artandantiquities@parks.nyc.gov to pre-register. The gallery is closed on federal holidays.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 360-8114

Location: The Arsenal

title: One Square Foot of Nature
description:
Date: April 4, 2022

There is so much to observe in the great outdoors, but it can be a little overwhelming to know what we’re looking at when there are so many things in our view. Sometimes, it’s a good idea to look small and close. Let’s take a short virtual trip to the forest floor and explore just one square foot of what lies beneath our feet in the woods. What can we see/feel/smell/hear in just a small space? What are some of the things we can identify, and what are some of the questions that are raised that we can walk away with to find out more?

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 11:00 am

title: Forest Fitness
description:
Date: April 5, 2022

Join the Fort Tryon Park Trust for a free, year-round “Fitness at the Fort” exercise program on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays! This regular fitness class incorporates climbing multiple staircases, stretches and strengthening exercises, notable tree identification, and forest bathing. Led by Nancy Bruning, BA, MPH, PAPHS.

Tuesdays at 7:30 a.m.: Easy Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance. Walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretching and cardio stair climbing. Walk south to Cabrini Woods for cardio steps and strengthening exercises and walk uphill to Billings Overlook for closing stretches.

Thursdays at 7:30 a.m.: Moderate Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance and walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretching and cardio stair climbing. Walk along the western path to Broadway, incorporating strengthening exercises, and walk uphill past Gazebo/Dog Run to Café Lawn, end with stretches.

Saturdays at 8:30 a.m.: Intense Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance and walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretch and cardio stair climbing. Walk along the western path to Broadway, incorporating strengthening exercises. Walk uphill towards Gazebo/Dog Run, utilizing a cluster of steps west of Broadway Path. Walk along the upper Alpine Garden path, to volleyball courts for stretches with final stair climbing to Margaret Corbin Circle.

(Note: Fitness Walking does not meet if it is raining or if the actual temperature or wind chill is below 20 degrees F.)

Start time: 7:30 am

End time: 8:30 am

Contact phone: (212) 795-1388

Location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)
location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)

title: Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy
description:
Date: April 5, 2022

See Frederick Law Olmsted’s lasting influence on park innovation in New York City with “Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy,” on view at the Arsenal Gallery in Central Park. The commemorative exhibition looks at recent NYC Parks projects that incorporate various Olmsted design principles, including site responsiveness, respect for nature, and the orchestration of movement. With renderings, site plans, and photos, the show highlights 10 park renovations throughout the city:

  • Bronx: Hugh Grant Circle/Virginia Park and Concrete Plant Park
  • Brooklyn: Lincoln Terrace Playground and Sunset Park Playground
  • Manhattan: Monsignor Kett Playground and Central Park’s Harlem Meer Center (formerly Lasker Rink and Pool)
  • Queens: Elmhurst Park and Bayswater Park
  • Staten Island: Faber Park and Richmond Terrace

April 26, 2022 marks the 200th anniversary of the birth of Frederick Law Olmsted (1822-1903), a pioneer landscape architect famous for his work co-designing Central Park, Prospect Park, and other well-known urban green spaces. From the democratization of public parks to the contouring of landscape and terrain to create a variety of visual experience, Olmsted was a seminal force in the design of our parks and how they are used.

Image: Concrete Plant Park, Bronx, 2009, NYC Parks / Jim Mituzas

Please note: Mask-wearing is required to enter the Arsenal Gallery, and guests are required to sign in. Groups of five or more people can call (212) 360-8114 or email artandantiquities@parks.nyc.gov to pre-register. The gallery is closed on federal holidays.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 360-8114

Location: The Arsenal

title: Workshop for Volunteers: Bringing Art to Local Parks, NYC Parks' Art in the Parks Program
description:
Date: April 5, 2022

For the first time, Partnerships for Parks is teaming up with NYC Parks’ Art in the Parks program to showcase the ways you can navigate the public art process to enrich your neighborhood park. You will see highlights from past installations and hear from a local artist who has had their work displayed through the Art in the Parks program.

Join us to learn:

  • The variety of artworks that have been exhibited in parks citywide
  • An overview of the public art process
  • Guidelines for applications

Featured speakers include:

  • Elizabeth Masella, Senior Public Art Coordinator for NYC Parks.
  • Naiomy Rodriguez, Public Art Coordinator for NYC Parks.

Registration for this session is required and will close the day before the event. You will receive information on how to join the webinar once you register. Traducción en Español disponible.

Photo by Patricia Cazorla & Nancy Saleme.

At Partnerships for Parks, we help people, organizations, and government work together to support NYC parks, gardens, trees, and other green spaces. Our free workshops are a great way to network and learn the skills needed to start, build, or sustain your park group.

Start time: 6:00 pm

End time: 7:00 pm

title: Short Film Surprise
description:
Date: April 5, 2022

Enter the beautiful world of short films. Short films usually range from a minute to half an hour and all of them do something that takes incredible skill to do: tell a captivating story in a short amount of time. In this program, instructor, Sidikha Ashraf will introduce students to short films from around the world, lead interesting discussions, and teach students how to write short film scripts of their own.
Sidikha is a member of Women in Animation, has written for DreamWorks Animation, and was trained in short film writing at the School of Visual Arts.

title: Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy
description:
Date: April 6, 2022

See Frederick Law Olmsted’s lasting influence on park innovation in New York City with “Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy,” on view at the Arsenal Gallery in Central Park. The commemorative exhibition looks at recent NYC Parks projects that incorporate various Olmsted design principles, including site responsiveness, respect for nature, and the orchestration of movement. With renderings, site plans, and photos, the show highlights 10 park renovations throughout the city:

  • Bronx: Hugh Grant Circle/Virginia Park and Concrete Plant Park
  • Brooklyn: Lincoln Terrace Playground and Sunset Park Playground
  • Manhattan: Monsignor Kett Playground and Central Park’s Harlem Meer Center (formerly Lasker Rink and Pool)
  • Queens: Elmhurst Park and Bayswater Park
  • Staten Island: Faber Park and Richmond Terrace

April 26, 2022 marks the 200th anniversary of the birth of Frederick Law Olmsted (1822-1903), a pioneer landscape architect famous for his work co-designing Central Park, Prospect Park, and other well-known urban green spaces. From the democratization of public parks to the contouring of landscape and terrain to create a variety of visual experience, Olmsted was a seminal force in the design of our parks and how they are used.

Image: Concrete Plant Park, Bronx, 2009, NYC Parks / Jim Mituzas

Please note: Mask-wearing is required to enter the Arsenal Gallery, and guests are required to sign in. Groups of five or more people can call (212) 360-8114 or email artandantiquities@parks.nyc.gov to pre-register. The gallery is closed on federal holidays.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 360-8114

Location: The Arsenal

description:

Participants are guided through writing for self-expression via virtual class. Participants encourage and support each other. Patrons may dictate or write their stories. The facilitator focuses on the participants' strengths to assure their success. Participants submit stories to compile for a production.

Sessions are fluid to allow for individual differences and participants select who or what they wish to write to.

Participants should have an interest in writing stories and memoirs.

To register, please call (718) 365-5516 or email Lucy.Aponte@parksnyc.gov.

title: Argentine Tango
description:
Date: April 6, 2022

Argentine Tango is a partner dance that developed over the last century in Argentina's capital city, Buenos Aires. It is very different from the Tango in International and American ballroom dancing. Argentine Tango is an interpretive, improvisational social dance that allows the dancers to develop a deep connection between themselves, the music, and the environment in which they are dancing.

title: Sunset Forest Bathing
description:
Date: April 6, 2022

We invite you to join us in reconnecting with nature by participating in a guided Forest Bathing experience. Allow yourself to connect with the park in a way you never have before. The program includes a short, no more than a half-mile walk at a slow pace. Participants are encouraged to wear comfortable clothing and bring water, snacks, and a towel or cushion for sitting on the ground.

Participants will meet in front of River Run Playground at 83rd Street at 6:00pm in Riverside Park. The guide will be wearing a purple and white backpack and will be stationed at the playground entrance.

Know Before You Go

For everyone's safety, we are asking all participants to observe the following guidelines:

  • Please wear a mask
  • All individuals should maintain social distancing of six feet during programming, regardless of vaccination status
  • Wash your hands before attending a program
  • Stay home if you are sick

Additionally, we encourage participants to bring their own hand sanitizer and water bottles to our programs.

Start time: 6:00 pm

End time: 7:30 pm

Contact phone: (212) 870-3070

title: Forest Fitness
description:
Date: April 7, 2022

Join the Fort Tryon Park Trust for a free, year-round “Fitness at the Fort” exercise program on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays! This regular fitness class incorporates climbing multiple staircases, stretches and strengthening exercises, notable tree identification, and forest bathing. Led by Nancy Bruning, BA, MPH, PAPHS.

Tuesdays at 7:30 a.m.: Easy Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance. Walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretching and cardio stair climbing. Walk south to Cabrini Woods for cardio steps and strengthening exercises and walk uphill to Billings Overlook for closing stretches.

Thursdays at 7:30 a.m.: Moderate Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance and walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretching and cardio stair climbing. Walk along the western path to Broadway, incorporating strengthening exercises, and walk uphill past Gazebo/Dog Run to Café Lawn, end with stretches.

Saturdays at 8:30 a.m.: Intense Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance and walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretch and cardio stair climbing. Walk along the western path to Broadway, incorporating strengthening exercises. Walk uphill towards Gazebo/Dog Run, utilizing a cluster of steps west of Broadway Path. Walk along the upper Alpine Garden path, to volleyball courts for stretches with final stair climbing to Margaret Corbin Circle.

(Note: Fitness Walking does not meet if it is raining or if the actual temperature or wind chill is below 20 degrees F.)

Start time: 7:30 am

End time: 8:30 am

Contact phone: 2127951388

Location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)
location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)
categories: Nature | Fitness | Seniors | Hiking | Exercise Classes | Strength Training/Weightlifting | Walking

title: Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy
description:
Date: April 7, 2022

See Frederick Law Olmsted’s lasting influence on park innovation in New York City with “Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy,” on view at the Arsenal Gallery in Central Park. The commemorative exhibition looks at recent NYC Parks projects that incorporate various Olmsted design principles, including site responsiveness, respect for nature, and the orchestration of movement. With renderings, site plans, and photos, the show highlights 10 park renovations throughout the city:

  • Bronx: Hugh Grant Circle/Virginia Park and Concrete Plant Park
  • Brooklyn: Lincoln Terrace Playground and Sunset Park Playground
  • Manhattan: Monsignor Kett Playground and Central Park’s Harlem Meer Center (formerly Lasker Rink and Pool)
  • Queens: Elmhurst Park and Bayswater Park
  • Staten Island: Faber Park and Richmond Terrace

April 26, 2022 marks the 200th anniversary of the birth of Frederick Law Olmsted (1822-1903), a pioneer landscape architect famous for his work co-designing Central Park, Prospect Park, and other well-known urban green spaces. From the democratization of public parks to the contouring of landscape and terrain to create a variety of visual experience, Olmsted was a seminal force in the design of our parks and how they are used.

Image: Concrete Plant Park, Bronx, 2009, NYC Parks / Jim Mituzas

Please note: Mask-wearing is required to enter the Arsenal Gallery, and guests are required to sign in. Groups of five or more people can call (212) 360-8114 or email artandantiquities@parks.nyc.gov to pre-register. The gallery is closed on federal holidays.

title: Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy
description:
Date: April 8, 2022

See Frederick Law Olmsted’s lasting influence on park innovation in New York City with “Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy,” on view at the Arsenal Gallery in Central Park. The commemorative exhibition looks at recent NYC Parks projects that incorporate various Olmsted design principles, including site responsiveness, respect for nature, and the orchestration of movement. With renderings, site plans, and photos, the show highlights 10 park renovations throughout the city:

  • Bronx: Hugh Grant Circle/Virginia Park and Concrete Plant Park
  • Brooklyn: Lincoln Terrace Playground and Sunset Park Playground
  • Manhattan: Monsignor Kett Playground and Central Park’s Harlem Meer Center (formerly Lasker Rink and Pool)
  • Queens: Elmhurst Park and Bayswater Park
  • Staten Island: Faber Park and Richmond Terrace

April 26, 2022 marks the 200th anniversary of the birth of Frederick Law Olmsted (1822-1903), a pioneer landscape architect famous for his work co-designing Central Park, Prospect Park, and other well-known urban green spaces. From the democratization of public parks to the contouring of landscape and terrain to create a variety of visual experience, Olmsted was a seminal force in the design of our parks and how they are used.

Image: Concrete Plant Park, Bronx, 2009, NYC Parks / Jim Mituzas

Please note: Mask-wearing is required to enter the Arsenal Gallery, and guests are required to sign in. Groups of five or more people can call (212) 360-8114 or email artandantiquities@parks.nyc.gov to pre-register. The gallery is closed on federal holidays.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 360-8114

Location: The Arsenal

title: Phragmites Friday
description:
Date: April 8, 2022

Join the Freshkills Park Alliance on April 8th for a Stewardship Project harvesting phragmites to make room for pollinator supporting native species. The phragmites will be used to support an art installation at Old Richmond Town. Learn how to identify the native and invasive plants while helping to understand the landscape! Ages 18+

Please note: As per NYC Parks policy, volunteers must sign an activity waiver in order to participate.

Register Online

Your ticket admits 1 car. Because of COVID-19 restrictions, all participants must provide their own car that will stay on-site the whole time. Participants may not use a bicycle, taxi, or ride-share service. Each ticket holder may bring up to 4 additional guests in their car. During registration, you will be asked about additional participants in your car. Due to limited reservations, carpooling with friends and family is encouraged.

Plan Ahead: Be "tick aware", wear long pants, close-toed shoes, and insect repellant. Also wear a hat and bring water and a snack. Tools, gloves, masks, and sanitizer will be provided. Do not attend if you are sick or have been exposed to COVID-19.

Can't make it? You can still help by promoting our volunteer projects with your friends and neighbors. Students can receive credit for community service hours. We will also be adding more volunteer opportunities as the season continues.

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 12:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 602-5372

Location: Freshkills Park Event Entrance

title: Bronx Urban Nature and Nature's Beauty
description:
Date: April 8, 2022

Enjoy an exhibition of photographs and graphics by Bronx artist Roy Secord rendered from nature photography shot during the pandemic.

Beautiful nature is closer than you think. This exhibition showcases the beauty of Bronx nature locations, many in close proximity to Poe Park. Roy Secord's work inspires viewers to explore and respectfully enjoy the incredible nature around us for our physical and psychological well-being.

“Nature’s Beauty” by Ace Photographers: Bronx Youth Nature Photography Program

An exhibition of nature photography by Roy Secord’s fine art and nature photography program by Bronx IS339 Middle School students. Sponsored by NYC Artist Corps Grant.

title: Wake Up, Daisy! at the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre
description:
Date: April 8, 2022

For more information on the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre, our COVID-19 policy and to purchase tickets, visit our website.

Wake Up, Daisy! tells the story of Daisy, a lively little girl living in the heart of New York City in an apartment overlooking Central Park. At Daisy’s much-anticipated birthday party, she encounters three special guests, known as her “Squad-parents”, from Brooklyn, Queens, and the Bronx who grant her the gifts of courage, knowledge, and a second chance. When an unwelcome guest shows up and casts a curse on her, Daisy’s life is forever changed. But through the support of her friends and an adventure throughout the city, Daisy’s strong self-determination and vivid imagination may be all she needs to break the curse.

Start time: 11:00 am

End time: 11:45 am

Contact phone: (212) 879-0794

title: A Life Lived - Oral Story Telling for Adults: Virtual and Live
description:
Date: April 8, 2022

Many older adults have lived a life they often do not share. In this class, participants will tell their stories to record for themselves or leave behind as a legacy for their families. They are the keepers of the family stories and have survived much like warriors. we will go through the developmental years from childhood into adulthood.

Childhood: What were you like as a child? (curious, rambunctious, creative, talkative, quiet, etc?) What caught your attention? What did you get into trouble for? (curiosity, creativity, being the oldest/youngest/middle child), Who were your role models? What did you do that was unusual? Did your childhood personality predict who you would be as an adult?

Stories may be submitted for publication. Writers and storytellers retain rights to their stories.

Please note: This class is open to adults via Zoom if unable to attend in person. To register for the Zoom link, please email Lucy.Aponte@parks.nyc.gov. In-person participation will take place at St. Mary's Recreation Center at 450 St. Ann's Avenue, Bron NY 10455.

Start time: 11:00 am

End time: 12:00 pm

Contact phone: (718) 365-5516

title: Wake Up, Daisy! at the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre
description:
Date: April 8, 2022

For more information on the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre, our COVID-19 policy and to purchase tickets, visit our website.

Wake Up, Daisy! tells the story of Daisy, a lively little girl living in the heart of New York City in an apartment overlooking Central Park. At Daisy’s much-anticipated birthday party, she encounters three special guests, known as her “Squad-parents”, from Brooklyn, Queens, and the Bronx who grant her the gifts of courage, knowledge, and a second chance. When an unwelcome guest shows up and casts a curse on her, Daisy’s life is forever changed. But through the support of her friends and an adventure throughout the city, Daisy’s strong self-determination and vivid imagination may be all she needs to break the curse.

Start time: 1:00 pm

End time: 1:45 am

Contact phone: (212) 879-0794

Location: Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre (in Central Park)

title: Volunteer Landscaping at Freshkills Park Studio + Gallery
description:
Date: April 8, 2022

The first annual Freshkills Park Earth Day Festival is coming to the New Springville Greenway on April 23, 2022. Join the Freshkills Park Alliance and NYC Parks for a volunteer day at our Studio + Gallery and help us get ready. Ages 18+

We will work together to remove harmful plants and debris, spread new soil, help with light pruning, and more!

Register online

Please note: As per NYC Parks policy, volunteers must sign an activity waiver and will be required to show proof they have received two doses of the Pfizer or Moderna vaccine, or the one dose of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine in order to participate.

Plan Ahead: Wear long pants, close-toed shoes, and insect repellant. Also wear a hat and bring water and a snack. Tools, gloves, masks, and sanitizer will be provided. Do not attend if you are sick or have been exposed to COVID-19.

Can't make it? You can still help by promoting our volunteer projects with your friends and neighbors. Students can receive credit for community service hours. We will also be adding more volunteer opportunities as the season continues. For more information about upcoming volunteer opportunities, check out our website at freshkillspark.org/volunteer.

Start time: 1:30 pm

End time: 3:30 pm

Contact phone: (212) 602-5372

Location: Freshkills Park Studio + Gallery

title: Forest Fitness
description:
Date: April 9, 2022

Join the Fort Tryon Park Trust for a free, year-round “Fitness at the Fort” exercise program on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays! This regular fitness class incorporates climbing multiple staircases, stretches and strengthening exercises, notable tree identification, and forest bathing. Led by Nancy Bruning, BA, MPH, PAPHS.

Tuesdays at 7:30 a.m.: Easy Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance. Walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretching and cardio stair climbing. Walk south to Cabrini Woods for cardio steps and strengthening exercises and walk uphill to Billings Overlook for closing stretches.

Thursdays at 7:30 a.m.: Moderate Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance and walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretching and cardio stair climbing. Walk along the western path to Broadway, incorporating strengthening exercises, and walk uphill past Gazebo/Dog Run to Café Lawn, end with stretches.

Saturdays at 8:30 a.m.: Intense Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance and walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretch and cardio stair climbing. Walk along the western path to Broadway, incorporating strengthening exercises. Walk uphill towards Gazebo/Dog Run, utilizing a cluster of steps west of Broadway Path. Walk along the upper Alpine Garden path, to volleyball courts for stretches with final stair climbing to Margaret Corbin Circle.

(Note: Fitness Walking does not meet if it is raining or if the actual temperature or wind chill is below 20 degrees F.)

Start time: 8:30 am

End time: 9:30 am

Contact phone: 2127951388

Location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)
location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)
categories: Nature | Fitness | Seniors | Hiking | Exercise Classes | Strength Training/Weightlifting | Walking

title: Second Saturdays Trailwork Party + Bike Share at Highbridge Bike Park
description:
Date: April 9, 2022

Dig, then ride with us on NYCMTB's monthly welcome days at Highbridge Park in Manhattan!

Bring your friends and family for a day of fun in the woods and learn what it takes to build, maintain, and ride the most progressive urban bike park in America! There will be light trail maintenance tasks for all ages from 10:00 a.m. to noon. All participants, NYCMTB members, or anyone with logged volunteer hours, receive a free 20-minute clinic and a guided ride throughout the trails from 12:30 p.m to 3:00 p.m. Bikes and helmets provided!

Highbridge Park is the home of NYC's first Mountain Biking Course. The 3-mile course offers trails of varying difficulty from intermediate to expert and a free-ride trail that includes drops, steeps, and berms. The park also features a dirt jump park and pump track, making it a good place to develop different skills at all levels. The course has been featured in national media and is stewarded by volunteers just like you!

Make this day your introduction to the park, or to the sport of off-road cycling. Interested volunteers are encouraged to participate regardless of age, ability or gender. There is something for everyone at Highbridge - It's NYC's bike park!

Please bring water, sunscreen, bug repellant, and sturdy shoes or boots.

Register on Eventbrite at nycmtb.eventbrite.com.

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 3:00 pm

Contact phone: (734) 358-2826

Location: BMX Jump Park (in Highbridge Park)
categories: Fitness | Best for Kids | Sports | Volunteer | Outdoor Fitness | Workshops

title: Broadway Berm Beautification Day - Fort Tryon Park
description:
Date: April 9, 2022

Join the Fort Tryon Park Trust and NYC Parks to dig in the dirt in Fort Tryon Park!

Meet at the Broadway Greeting Garden at the Arden Street/Broadway entrance. Wear long pants, sturdy shoes, and get ready to improve the park’s ecology by removing debris and helping site preparations. Tools and gloves will be provided but please bring a filled water bottle.

Groups of 5+ must RSVP by emailing info@FortTryonParkTrust.org two weeks in advance.

Volunteers under age 18 must be accompanied by an adult.

Stewardship Days along the eastern expanse of the park take place on the 2nd and 4th Saturdays of each month from March through November. The Fort Tryon Park Trust supports these volunteer opportunities by underwriting tools, horticultural supplies, and NYC Parks staffing to oversee projects.

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 1:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 795-1388

Location: Broadway and Arden Street (in Fort Tryon Park)

title: Introduction to Birdwatching Walks
description:
Date: April 9, 2022

Whether you’re just starting out or have already joined the birding ranks, this introductory walk is for you! Every Saturday, join a member of the Brooklyn Bird Club and Prospect Park Alliance on an introductory walk to learn the basics of birding and search for the dozens of species that visit Prospect Park through all seasons.

All levels are welcome and walks will begin at the Prospect Park Audubon Center. No registration necessary. Children under 12 must be accompanied by an adult. Please bring binoculars if you have them.

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 12:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Audubon Center at the Boathouse (in Prospect Park)
location: Audubon Center at the Boathouse (in Prospect Park)

title: Weekend Nature Exploration
description:
Date: April 9, 2022

Join the Prospect Park Alliance for nature education programs on Saturdays and Sundays at the Prospect Park Audubon Center, the first urban Audubon Center in the nation.

Discovery Pack, 10 am–12 pm: Come explore nature on your own with our Discovery Packs, a backpack filled with nature activities and exploration tools, perfect for families and kids to interact with the park in a whole new way!
Animal Encounter, 11 am–12 pm: Join Alliance Naturalists in learning more about the animals in the Audubon Center’s collection. This program starts promptly at 11 am.
Nature’s Helpers, 12–1 pm: Help do your part to keep Prospect Park healthy by cleaning up the lakeshore. In this citizen science activity Audubon staff will guide groups to remove litter and record the findings. Fun for all ages and all materials are provided. This program departs from the Audubon Center promptly at 12 pm.

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 1:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Audubon Center at the Boathouse (in Prospect Park)
location: Audubon Center at the Boathouse (in Prospect Park)

title: Bronx Urban Nature and Nature's Beauty
description:
Date: April 9, 2022

Enjoy an exhibition of photographs and graphics by Bronx artist Roy Secord rendered from nature photography shot during the pandemic.

Beautiful nature is closer than you think. This exhibition showcases the beauty of Bronx nature locations, many in close proximity to Poe Park. Roy Secord's work inspires viewers to explore and respectfully enjoy the incredible nature around us for our physical and psychological well-being.

“Nature’s Beauty” by Ace Photographers: Bronx Youth Nature Photography Program

An exhibition of nature photography by Roy Secord’s fine art and nature photography program by Bronx IS339 Middle School students. Sponsored by NYC Artist Corps Grant.

title: Wake Up, Daisy! at the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre
description:
Date: April 9, 2022

For more information on the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre, our COVID-19 policy and to purchase tickets, visit our website.

Wake Up, Daisy! tells the story of Daisy, a lively little girl living in the heart of New York City in an apartment overlooking Central Park. At Daisy’s much-anticipated birthday party, she encounters three special guests, known as her “Squad-parents”, from Brooklyn, Queens, and the Bronx who grant her the gifts of courage, knowledge, and a second chance. When an unwelcome guest shows up and casts a curse on her, Daisy’s life is forever changed. But through the support of her friends and an adventure throughout the city, Daisy’s strong self-determination and vivid imagination may be all she needs to break the curse.

Start time: 11:00 am

Contact phone: (212) 879-0794

title: Fort Tryon Kids: Endangered Species
description:
Date: April 9, 2022

Join the Fort Tryon Park Trust and the Alley Pond Environmental Center to learn more about how we can protect wildlife! This vital program will distinguish between the terms threatened, endangered, and extinct, allowing students to understand why so many animal populations are disappearing at an alarming rate. Additionally, participants will examine products of the illegal wildlife trade and learn how you can play a part in protecting threatened species. APEC instructors will bring live animals, including a chinchilla & tiger salamander, to this free children’s program.

Start time: 1:00 pm

End time: 2:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 795-1388

title: Wake Up, Daisy! at the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre
description:
Date: April 9, 2022

For more information on the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre, our COVID-19 policy and to purchase tickets, visit our website.

Wake Up, Daisy! tells the story of Daisy, a lively little girl living in the heart of New York City in an apartment overlooking Central Park. At Daisy’s much-anticipated birthday party, she encounters three special guests, known as her “Squad-parents”, from Brooklyn, Queens, and the Bronx who grant her the gifts of courage, knowledge, and a second chance. When an unwelcome guest shows up and casts a curse on her, Daisy’s life is forever changed. But through the support of her friends and an adventure throughout the city, Daisy’s strong self-determination and vivid imagination may be all she needs to break the curse.

Start time: 1:00 pm

End time: 1:45 am

Contact phone: (212) 879-0794

title: Kayak Tour
description:
Date: April 9, 2022

Kayak along Freshkills Park's waterways! This two-mile round-trip paddle is a chance to explore the creeks and shorelines of Freshkills Park and experience the wildlife while the site is closed to the public. We know this program fills quickly and wish we could offer it more frequently. But we have a small staff and are generally limited to trips on the weekend during high tide.

There is a $20 suggested donation per participant. Your donation supports education, programming, and research at the Freshkills Park Alliance and makes programs like this possible.

Your ticket admits 1 car. Because of COVID-19 restrictions, all participants must provide their own car that will stay on-site the whole time. Participants may not use a bicycle, taxi or ride-share service. Each ticket holder may bring up to 3 additional guests in their car. During registration, you will be asked about additional participants in your car. Due to limited reservations, carpooling with friends and family is encouraged.

Register online

Location provided with confirmation email: We will meet and caravan onto the Freshkills Park site together.

Plan Ahead: Wear sturdy shoes that you don’t mind getting wet or muddy and clothes that can get wet. Please also bring water and sunblock. Kayaks and life jackets will be provided. You will be asked to sign an activity waiver before participating in the program. Do not attend if you are sick or have been exposed to COVID-19.

Start time: 1:30 pm

End time: 4:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 602-5372

Location: Freshkills Park Event Entrance
categories: Nature | Tours | Kayaking and Canoeing | Waterfront

title: Weekend Nature Exploration
description:
Date: April 10, 2022

Join the Prospect Park Alliance for nature education programs on Saturdays and Sundays at the Prospect Park Audubon Center, the first urban Audubon Center in the nation.

Discovery Pack, 10 am–12 pm: Come explore nature on your own with our Discovery Packs, a backpack filled with nature activities and exploration tools, perfect for families and kids to interact with the park in a whole new way!
Animal Encounter, 11 am–12 pm: Join Alliance Naturalists in learning more about the animals in the Audubon Center’s collection. This program starts promptly at 11 am.
Nature’s Helpers, 12–1 pm: Help do your part to keep Prospect Park healthy by cleaning up the lakeshore. In this citizen science activity Audubon staff will guide groups to remove litter and record the findings. Fun for all ages and all materials are provided. This program departs from the Audubon Center promptly at 12 pm.

title: Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy
description:
Date: April 11, 2022

See Frederick Law Olmsted’s lasting influence on park innovation in New York City with “Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy,” on view at the Arsenal Gallery in Central Park. The commemorative exhibition looks at recent NYC Parks projects that incorporate various Olmsted design principles, including site responsiveness, respect for nature, and the orchestration of movement. With renderings, site plans, and photos, the show highlights 10 park renovations throughout the city:

  • Bronx: Hugh Grant Circle/Virginia Park and Concrete Plant Park
  • Brooklyn: Lincoln Terrace Playground and Sunset Park Playground
  • Manhattan: Monsignor Kett Playground and Central Park’s Harlem Meer Center (formerly Lasker Rink and Pool)
  • Queens: Elmhurst Park and Bayswater Park
  • Staten Island: Faber Park and Richmond Terrace

April 26, 2022 marks the 200th anniversary of the birth of Frederick Law Olmsted (1822-1903), a pioneer landscape architect famous for his work co-designing Central Park, Prospect Park, and other well-known urban green spaces. From the democratization of public parks to the contouring of landscape and terrain to create a variety of visual experience, Olmsted was a seminal force in the design of our parks and how they are used.

Image: Concrete Plant Park, Bronx, 2009, NYC Parks / Jim Mituzas

Please note: Mask-wearing is required to enter the Arsenal Gallery, and guests are required to sign in. Groups of five or more people can call (212) 360-8114 or email artandantiquities@parks.nyc.gov to pre-register. The gallery is closed on federal holidays.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 360-8114

Location: The Arsenal

title: Forest Fitness
description:
Date: April 12, 2022

Join the Fort Tryon Park Trust for a free, year-round “Fitness at the Fort” exercise program on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays! This regular fitness class incorporates climbing multiple staircases, stretches and strengthening exercises, notable tree identification, and forest bathing. Led by Nancy Bruning, BA, MPH, PAPHS.

Tuesdays at 7:30 a.m.: Easy Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance. Walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretching and cardio stair climbing. Walk south to Cabrini Woods for cardio steps and strengthening exercises and walk uphill to Billings Overlook for closing stretches.

Thursdays at 7:30 a.m.: Moderate Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance and walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretching and cardio stair climbing. Walk along the western path to Broadway, incorporating strengthening exercises, and walk uphill past Gazebo/Dog Run to Café Lawn, end with stretches.

Saturdays at 8:30 a.m.: Intense Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance and walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretch and cardio stair climbing. Walk along the western path to Broadway, incorporating strengthening exercises. Walk uphill towards Gazebo/Dog Run, utilizing a cluster of steps west of Broadway Path. Walk along the upper Alpine Garden path, to volleyball courts for stretches with final stair climbing to Margaret Corbin Circle.

(Note: Fitness Walking does not meet if it is raining or if the actual temperature or wind chill is below 20 degrees F.)

Start time: 7:30 am

End time: 8:30 am

Contact phone: (212) 795-1388

Location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)
location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)
categories: Nature | Fitness | Outdoor Fitness | Seniors | Hiking | Strength Training/Weightlifting | Walking

title: Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy
description:
Date: April 12, 2022

See Frederick Law Olmsted’s lasting influence on park innovation in New York City with “Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy,” on view at the Arsenal Gallery in Central Park. The commemorative exhibition looks at recent NYC Parks projects that incorporate various Olmsted design principles, including site responsiveness, respect for nature, and the orchestration of movement. With renderings, site plans, and photos, the show highlights 10 park renovations throughout the city:

  • Bronx: Hugh Grant Circle/Virginia Park and Concrete Plant Park
  • Brooklyn: Lincoln Terrace Playground and Sunset Park Playground
  • Manhattan: Monsignor Kett Playground and Central Park’s Harlem Meer Center (formerly Lasker Rink and Pool)
  • Queens: Elmhurst Park and Bayswater Park
  • Staten Island: Faber Park and Richmond Terrace

April 26, 2022 marks the 200th anniversary of the birth of Frederick Law Olmsted (1822-1903), a pioneer landscape architect famous for his work co-designing Central Park, Prospect Park, and other well-known urban green spaces. From the democratization of public parks to the contouring of landscape and terrain to create a variety of visual experience, Olmsted was a seminal force in the design of our parks and how they are used.

Image: Concrete Plant Park, Bronx, 2009, NYC Parks / Jim Mituzas

Please note: Mask-wearing is required to enter the Arsenal Gallery, and guests are required to sign in. Groups of five or more people can call (212) 360-8114 or email artandantiquities@parks.nyc.gov to pre-register. The gallery is closed on federal holidays.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 360-8114

Location: The Arsenal

Beautiful nature is closer than you think. This exhibition showcases the beauty of Bronx nature locations, many in close proximity to Poe Park. Roy Secord's work inspires viewers to explore and respectfully enjoy the incredible nature around us for our physical and psychological well-being.

“Nature’s Beauty” by Ace Photographers: Bronx Youth Nature Photography Program

An exhibition of nature photography by Roy Secord’s fine art and nature photography program by Bronx IS339 Middle School students. Sponsored by NYC Artist Corps Grant.

title: Olmsted 200: Parks in Conversation—Virtual Tour of Central Park and Prospect Park
description:
Date: April 12, 2022

Join Prospect Park Alliance and Turnstile Tours for a virtual tour in celebration of Frederick Law Olmsted’s 200th birthday that explores two of his New York City masterpieces—Central Park and Prospect Park. Central Park guides will highlight the park’s arches, meadows, and natural features, while Turnstile Tours guides will examine parallel features in Prospect Park and compare and contrast the different elements of the parks, including examples of Olmsted designs that have been adapted to fit better with modern-day recreational uses and ecological practices. Built a decade apart, the parks share many similarities, but also reflect Olmsted’s evolution as a park designer, and both speak to his lasting influence on landscape design and public space.

Start time: 12:30 pm

End time: 1:15 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Virtual/Online Workshop

title: Conceptualizing with Graffiti
description:
Date: April 12, 2022

Join us and learn the fundamentals involved with being a graffiti artist with classes led by artist Kidlew. Each workshop will touch base on a different element of graffiti art such as: What do you Write?, Tagging Slaps, Characters, Map it out, and Canvas. All levels welcome. Supplies will be provided.
Born in Queens, NY, Chorean (half Chinese / half Korean) and colorblind artist Kidlew started drawing at an early age copying Disney characters straight from his juice cup onto construction paper. Riding the subway's in the 70's with his grandmother, Kidlew incorporated this world into his own artwork and later took to the ever growing NYC 80's pop culture, world of skateboarding and graffiti. Kidlew has developed his own characters and personal style into the "Made in Chorea" and "Haloz Wuz Here" brands (both based on characters that tell stories depicting his personal life experiences).


Start time: 3:00 pm

End time: 5:00 pm

title: The Drawing Fundamentals of Portraits, Pets and Florals
description:
Date: April 12, 2022

April 12 Drawing Self Portraits
As humans, one thing that determines how we interact with this world is our self-image. Some have very strong self-image, while some of us are still learning to see how awesome we are. With drawing we will learn to create our own unique likeness!

April 19 Drawing our Pets
We love our pets, and what could be better than learning how to draw our beloved animal friend. Bring in a picture of your favorite pet (or your friends or family's favorite pet), and we will all learn to capture their personality through drawing.

April 26 Painting Florals
It’s a welcome to springtime. The flowers are blooming, and this is the perfect workshop to learn the fundamentals of floral drawing + painting.



Bio
Joshuah Filemon is an illustrator and musician, born and raised in Bushwick. He is drawn to alternative forms of music and media as a child and embraced his urban roots as he grew into an adult. His art is a reflection of just that, edgy and alternative with that New York, urban flare! Joshuah is a graduate of the Fashion Institute of Technology.

title: Artist’s Talk: Community Garden Leader Photo Essay and Oral History Project
description:
Date: April 12, 2022

Since 2018, photographer Zachary Schulman has been documenting community garden leaders in New York City through portraits and interviews. Taking on even greater meaning during the pandemic, Zack’s portraits offer a New York perspective on a global experience of finding safe haven, as well as joy, community, mental health support, and fresh food, all through community gardening. In this webinar, Zack will share photos and stories of community gardeners and share tips with gardeners looking to document their garden’s stories.

Register on Eventbrite to receive a Zoom link to join this free virtual artist talk.

Zachary Schulman is a New York City-based photographer dedicated to crafting images that advance movements for social change and support progressive nonprofits. He’s a member of Walt L. Shamel Community Garden in Crown Heights, Brooklyn where he co-manages the public composting program. When he’s not gardening, he can be found cooking, fermenting, or biking to the beach. Find more of his work at zacharyschulman.com.

Photo: Patti Hagan, St. Marks Avenue / Prospect Heights Community Garden, Prospect Heights, Brooklyn by Zachary Schulman

Start time: 6:00 pm

End time: 7:30 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Virtual/Online Workshop

title: Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy
description:
Date: April 13, 2022

See Frederick Law Olmsted’s lasting influence on park innovation in New York City with “Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy,” on view at the Arsenal Gallery in Central Park. The commemorative exhibition looks at recent NYC Parks projects that incorporate various Olmsted design principles, including site responsiveness, respect for nature, and the orchestration of movement. With renderings, site plans, and photos, the show highlights 10 park renovations throughout the city:

  • Bronx: Hugh Grant Circle/Virginia Park and Concrete Plant Park
  • Brooklyn: Lincoln Terrace Playground and Sunset Park Playground
  • Manhattan: Monsignor Kett Playground and Central Park’s Harlem Meer Center (formerly Lasker Rink and Pool)
  • Queens: Elmhurst Park and Bayswater Park
  • Staten Island: Faber Park and Richmond Terrace

April 26, 2022 marks the 200th anniversary of the birth of Frederick Law Olmsted (1822-1903), a pioneer landscape architect famous for his work co-designing Central Park, Prospect Park, and other well-known urban green spaces. From the democratization of public parks to the contouring of landscape and terrain to create a variety of visual experience, Olmsted was a seminal force in the design of our parks and how they are used.

Image: Concrete Plant Park, Bronx, 2009, NYC Parks / Jim Mituzas

Please note: Mask-wearing is required to enter the Arsenal Gallery, and guests are required to sign in. Groups of five or more people can call (212) 360-8114 or email artandantiquities@parks.nyc.gov to pre-register. The gallery is closed on federal holidays.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 360-8114

Location: The Arsenal

title: Argentine Tango
description:
Date: April 13, 2022

Argentine Tango is a partner dance that developed over the last century in Argentina's capital city, Buenos Aires. It is very different from the Tango in International and American ballroom dancing. Argentine Tango is an interpretive, improvisational social dance that allows the dancers to develop a deep connection between themselves, the music, and the environment in which they are dancing.

title: Forest Fitness
description:
Date: April 14, 2022

Join the Fort Tryon Park Trust for a free, year-round “Fitness at the Fort” exercise program on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays! This regular fitness class incorporates climbing multiple staircases, stretches and strengthening exercises, notable tree identification, and forest bathing. Led by Nancy Bruning, BA, MPH, PAPHS.

Tuesdays at 7:30 a.m.: Easy Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance. Walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretching and cardio stair climbing. Walk south to Cabrini Woods for cardio steps and strengthening exercises and walk uphill to Billings Overlook for closing stretches.

Thursdays at 7:30 a.m.: Moderate Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance and walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretching and cardio stair climbing. Walk along the western path to Broadway, incorporating strengthening exercises, and walk uphill past Gazebo/Dog Run to Café Lawn, end with stretches.

Saturdays at 8:30 a.m.: Intense Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance and walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretch and cardio stair climbing. Walk along the western path to Broadway, incorporating strengthening exercises. Walk uphill towards Gazebo/Dog Run, utilizing a cluster of steps west of Broadway Path. Walk along the upper Alpine Garden path, to volleyball courts for stretches with final stair climbing to Margaret Corbin Circle.

(Note: Fitness Walking does not meet if it is raining or if the actual temperature or wind chill is below 20 degrees F.)

Start time: 7:30 am

End time: 8:30 am

Contact phone: 2127951388

Location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)
location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)

title: Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy
description:
Date: April 14, 2022

See Frederick Law Olmsted’s lasting influence on park innovation in New York City with “Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy,” on view at the Arsenal Gallery in Central Park. The commemorative exhibition looks at recent NYC Parks projects that incorporate various Olmsted design principles, including site responsiveness, respect for nature, and the orchestration of movement. With renderings, site plans, and photos, the show highlights 10 park renovations throughout the city:

  • Bronx: Hugh Grant Circle/Virginia Park and Concrete Plant Park
  • Brooklyn: Lincoln Terrace Playground and Sunset Park Playground
  • Manhattan: Monsignor Kett Playground and Central Park’s Harlem Meer Center (formerly Lasker Rink and Pool)
  • Queens: Elmhurst Park and Bayswater Park
  • Staten Island: Faber Park and Richmond Terrace

April 26, 2022 marks the 200th anniversary of the birth of Frederick Law Olmsted (1822-1903), a pioneer landscape architect famous for his work co-designing Central Park, Prospect Park, and other well-known urban green spaces. From the democratization of public parks to the contouring of landscape and terrain to create a variety of visual experience, Olmsted was a seminal force in the design of our parks and how they are used.

Image: Concrete Plant Park, Bronx, 2009, NYC Parks / Jim Mituzas

Please note: Mask-wearing is required to enter the Arsenal Gallery, and guests are required to sign in. Groups of five or more people can call (212) 360-8114 or email artandantiquities@parks.nyc.gov to pre-register. The gallery is closed on federal holidays.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 360-8114

Location: The Arsenal

title: Conceptualizing with Graffiti
description:
Date: April 14, 2022

Join us and learn the fundamentals involved with being a graffiti artist with classes led by artist Kidlew. Each workshop will touch base on a different element of graffiti art such as: What do you Write?, Tagging Slaps, Characters, Map it out, and Canvas. All levels welcome. Supplies will be provided.

Born in Queens, NY, Chorean (half Chinese / half Korean) and colorblind artist Kidlew started drawing at an early age copying Disney characters straight from his juice cup onto construction paper. Riding the subway's in the 70's with his grandmother, Kidlew incorporated this world into his own artwork and later took to the ever growing NYC 80's pop culture, world of skateboarding and graffiti. Kidlew has developed his own characters and personal style into the "Made in Chorea" and "Haloz Wuz Here" brands (both based on characters that tell stories depicting his personal life experiences).

Start time: 3:00 pm

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone:

title: Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy
description:
Date: April 15, 2022

See Frederick Law Olmsted’s lasting influence on park innovation in New York City with “Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy,” on view at the Arsenal Gallery in Central Park. The commemorative exhibition looks at recent NYC Parks projects that incorporate various Olmsted design principles, including site responsiveness, respect for nature, and the orchestration of movement. With renderings, site plans, and photos, the show highlights 10 park renovations throughout the city:

  • Bronx: Hugh Grant Circle/Virginia Park and Concrete Plant Park
  • Brooklyn: Lincoln Terrace Playground and Sunset Park Playground
  • Manhattan: Monsignor Kett Playground and Central Park’s Harlem Meer Center (formerly Lasker Rink and Pool)
  • Queens: Elmhurst Park and Bayswater Park
  • Staten Island: Faber Park and Richmond Terrace

April 26, 2022 marks the 200th anniversary of the birth of Frederick Law Olmsted (1822-1903), a pioneer landscape architect famous for his work co-designing Central Park, Prospect Park, and other well-known urban green spaces. From the democratization of public parks to the contouring of landscape and terrain to create a variety of visual experience, Olmsted was a seminal force in the design of our parks and how they are used.

Image: Concrete Plant Park, Bronx, 2009, NYC Parks / Jim Mituzas

Please note: Mask-wearing is required to enter the Arsenal Gallery, and guests are required to sign in. Groups of five or more people can call (212) 360-8114 or email artandantiquities@parks.nyc.gov to pre-register. The gallery is closed on federal holidays.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 360-8114

Location: The Arsenal

title: Bronx Urban Nature and Nature's Beauty
description:
Date: April 15, 2022

Enjoy an exhibition of photographs and graphics by Bronx artist Roy Secord rendered from nature photography shot during the pandemic.

Beautiful nature is closer than you think. This exhibition showcases the beauty of Bronx nature locations, many in close proximity to Poe Park. Roy Secord's work inspires viewers to explore and respectfully enjoy the incredible nature around us for our physical and psychological well-being.

“Nature’s Beauty” by Ace Photographers: Bronx Youth Nature Photography Program

An exhibition of nature photography by Roy Secord’s fine art and nature photography program by Bronx IS339 Middle School students. Sponsored by NYC Artist Corps Grant.

title: Wake Up, Daisy! at the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre
description:
Date: April 15, 2022

For more information on the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre, our COVID-19 policy and to purchase tickets, visit our website.

Wake Up, Daisy! tells the story of Daisy, a lively little girl living in the heart of New York City in an apartment overlooking Central Park. At Daisy’s much-anticipated birthday party, she encounters three special guests, known as her “Squad-parents”, from Brooklyn, Queens, and the Bronx who grant her the gifts of courage, knowledge, and a second chance. When an unwelcome guest shows up and casts a curse on her, Daisy’s life is forever changed. But through the support of her friends and an adventure throughout the city, Daisy’s strong self-determination and vivid imagination may be all she needs to break the curse.

Start time: 11:00 am

End time: 11:45 am

Contact phone: (212) 879-0794

title: A Life Lived - Oral Story Telling for Adults: Virtual and Live
description:
Date: April 15, 2022

Many older adults have lived a life they often do not share. In this class, participants will tell their stories to record for themselves or leave behind as a legacy for their families. They are the keepers of the family stories and have survived much like warriors. we will go through the developmental years from childhood into adulthood.

Childhood: What were you like as a child? (curious, rambunctious, creative, talkative, quiet, etc?) What caught your attention? What did you get into trouble for? (curiosity, creativity, being the oldest/youngest/middle child), Who were your role models? What did you do that was unusual? Did your childhood personality predict who you would be as an adult?

Stories may be submitted for publication. Writers and storytellers retain rights to their stories.

Please note: This class is open to adults via Zoom if unable to attend in person. To register for the Zoom link, please email Lucy.Aponte@parks.nyc.gov. In-person participation will take place at St. Mary's Recreation Center at 450 St. Ann's Avenue, Bron NY 10455.

Start time: 11:00 am

End time: 12:00 pm

Contact phone: (718) 365-5516

title: Wake Up, Daisy! at the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre
description:
Date: April 15, 2022

For more information on the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre, our COVID-19 policy and to purchase tickets, visit our website.

Wake Up, Daisy! tells the story of Daisy, a lively little girl living in the heart of New York City in an apartment overlooking Central Park. At Daisy’s much-anticipated birthday party, she encounters three special guests, known as her “Squad-parents”, from Brooklyn, Queens, and the Bronx who grant her the gifts of courage, knowledge, and a second chance. When an unwelcome guest shows up and casts a curse on her, Daisy’s life is forever changed. But through the support of her friends and an adventure throughout the city, Daisy’s strong self-determination and vivid imagination may be all she needs to break the curse.

Start time: 1:00 pm

End time: 1:45 am

Contact phone: (212) 879-0794

Location: Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre (in Central Park)

title: Forest Fitness
description:
Date: April 16, 2022

Join the Fort Tryon Park Trust for a free, year-round “Fitness at the Fort” exercise program on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays! This regular fitness class incorporates climbing multiple staircases, stretches and strengthening exercises, notable tree identification, and forest bathing. Led by Nancy Bruning, BA, MPH, PAPHS.

Tuesdays at 7:30 a.m.: Easy Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance. Walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretching and cardio stair climbing. Walk south to Cabrini Woods for cardio steps and strengthening exercises and walk uphill to Billings Overlook for closing stretches.

Thursdays at 7:30 a.m.: Moderate Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance and walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretching and cardio stair climbing. Walk along the western path to Broadway, incorporating strengthening exercises, and walk uphill past Gazebo/Dog Run to Café Lawn, end with stretches.

Saturdays at 8:30 a.m.: Intense Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance and walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretch and cardio stair climbing. Walk along the western path to Broadway, incorporating strengthening exercises. Walk uphill towards Gazebo/Dog Run, utilizing a cluster of steps west of Broadway Path. Walk along the upper Alpine Garden path, to volleyball courts for stretches with final stair climbing to Margaret Corbin Circle.

(Note: Fitness Walking does not meet if it is raining or if the actual temperature or wind chill is below 20 degrees F.)

Start time: 8:30 am

End time: 9:30 am

Contact phone: 2127951388

Location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)
location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)
categories: Nature | Fitness | Seniors | Hiking | Exercise Classes | Strength Training/Weightlifting | Walking

title: Family Fun Hike: Celebrating Planet Earth
description:
Date: April 16, 2022

Family Fun Hikes in Van Cortlandt Park. For 2 to 6 year olds and their adult(s). Led by a Van Cortlandt Park Alliance educator!

Celebrating Planet Earth!

Let’s come together to celebrate all the wild creatures on planet Earth! Keep your eyes and ears open for signs of forest creatures. Van Cortlandt Park is home to squirrels, raccoons, chipmunks, and the occasional groundhog. Can you spot a nest? Or a secret burrow? Afterward, let’s create our own creatures using pinecones and other natural materials.

Read Aloud Story: My Friend Earth by Patricia MacLachlan

RSVP on Eventbrite

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 12:00 pm

Contact phone: (718) 601-1460

title: Garlic Mustard Pull
description:
Date: April 16, 2022

Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx is home to 640 acres of forest and wetlands. Garlic mustard threatens the biodiversity within the park.

Join Van Cortlandt Park Alliance in removing garlic mustard from the understory of Van Cortlandt Park. It is fun and easy to remove!

Wear long pants and sturdy shoes. Bring along plenty of water.

Please be advised as of 12/27/21, a vaccine mandate has been ordered by the City of New York. In order to participate in Van Cortlandt Park Alliance volunteer events, all volunteers must be vaccinated.

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 1:00 pm

title: Introduction to Birdwatching Walks
description:
Date: April 16, 2022

Whether you’re just starting out or have already joined the birding ranks, this introductory walk is for you! Every Saturday, join a member of the Brooklyn Bird Club and Prospect Park Alliance on an introductory walk to learn the basics of birding and search for the dozens of species that visit Prospect Park through all seasons.

All levels are welcome and walks will begin at the Prospect Park Audubon Center. No registration necessary. Children under 12 must be accompanied by an adult. Please bring binoculars if you have them.

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 12:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Audubon Center at the Boathouse (in Prospect Park)
location: Audubon Center at the Boathouse (in Prospect Park)

title: Weekend Nature Exploration
description:
Date: April 16, 2022

Join the Prospect Park Alliance for nature education programs on Saturdays and Sundays at the Prospect Park Audubon Center, the first urban Audubon Center in the nation.

Discovery Pack, 10 am–12 pm: Come explore nature on your own with our Discovery Packs, a backpack filled with nature activities and exploration tools, perfect for families and kids to interact with the park in a whole new way!
Animal Encounter, 11 am–12 pm: Join Alliance Naturalists in learning more about the animals in the Audubon Center’s collection. This program starts promptly at 11 am.
Nature’s Helpers, 12–1 pm: Help do your part to keep Prospect Park healthy by cleaning up the lakeshore. In this citizen science activity Audubon staff will guide groups to remove litter and record the findings. Fun for all ages and all materials are provided. This program departs from the Audubon Center promptly at 12 pm.

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 1:00 pm

Location: Audubon Center at the Boathouse (in Prospect Park)

title: Bronx Urban Nature and Nature's Beauty
description:
Date: April 16, 2022

Enjoy an exhibition of photographs and graphics by Bronx artist Roy Secord rendered from nature photography shot during the pandemic.

Beautiful nature is closer than you think. This exhibition showcases the beauty of Bronx nature locations, many in close proximity to Poe Park. Roy Secord's work inspires viewers to explore and respectfully enjoy the incredible nature around us for our physical and psychological well-being.

“Nature’s Beauty” by Ace Photographers: Bronx Youth Nature Photography Program

An exhibition of nature photography by Roy Secord’s fine art and nature photography program by Bronx IS339 Middle School students. Sponsored by NYC Artist Corps Grant.

description:
Date: April 16, 2022

For more information on the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre, our COVID-19 policy and to purchase tickets, visit our website.

Wake Up, Daisy! tells the story of Daisy, a lively little girl living in the heart of New York City in an apartment overlooking Central Park. At Daisy’s much-anticipated birthday party, she encounters three special guests, known as her “Squad-parents”, from Brooklyn, Queens, and the Bronx who grant her the gifts of courage, knowledge, and a second chance. When an unwelcome guest shows up and casts a curse on her, Daisy’s life is forever changed. But through the support of her friends and an adventure throughout the city, Daisy’s strong self-determination and vivid imagination may be all she needs to break the curse.
